oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Book Fair at Vanderbilt University

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Poster announcing a book fair to be held at the Alumni Memorial Hall at Vanderbilt University. The guest speakers include Robert Penn Warren and Robert Henry. Also listed are the companies that will have displays at the fair, which is sponsored by the Nashville Library Club. It is scheduled to take place November 13-15, 1933.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Posters; Book fairs; Exhibitions; Bookstores; Book talks; Universities & colleges
Broadsides; Vanderbilt University; Warren, Robert Penn, 1905-1989
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Nashville Library Club
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Penn Warren (April 24, 1905-September 15, 1989) was an American poet, novelist, and literary critic, as well as one of the founders of New Criticism. He was also a charter member of the Fellowship of Southern Writers. He received the 1947 Pulitzer Prize for his novel "All the King's Men" (1946) and, in 1957 and 1979, the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry. At Vanderbilt, he was associated with the literary group known as The Fugitives.
